data: {"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3075572,"name":"Sam Belliveau","username":"Sampajama","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/sampajama/{size}/180943_2.png","created_at":"2022-08-03T00:43:07.353Z","cooked":"\u003cp\u003eSo our team has not used a Swerve Drive in any of our seasons before, but we were experimenting with it using the simulation tools within WPILib. We noticed that when doing field relative controls, if you turned while moving, you would slightly drift in the direction you were turning. We thought that this was because the PID loops were not perfect (which does contribute to some drifting), but even when we simulate perfect modules, there is still a bit of drift while moving and turning.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWe soon realized that this is a bi-product of controlling the robot in discrete time steps. As you can see from \u003ca href=\"https://www.desmos.com/calculator/27a73vzmox\" rel=\"noopener nofollow ugc\"\u003ethis desmos we made\u003c/a\u003e, the swerve drive will drift slightly in the direction you’re turning due to the robot traveling in a curved path. We also found the exact amount you can rotate your translation vector by to account for this which is \u003ccode\u003e0.5 * w * dt\u003c/code\u003e where w is your angular velocity and dt is the time between each robot update. But even this wasn’t perfect, because when your swerve drive desaturates the motor velocities, it changes your angular velocity, so you need to adjust w based on how much your wheels are being desaturated. Accounting for all of this, we were able to get our swerve drive to move in a straight line while turning in the simulation.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eHowever more issues arose when we simulated our PID loop. Because the modules were not perfectly following their trajectories, the robot would drift while moving and turning. We are using NEO’s on our swerve drive as we do not have access to falcons, which makes the PID loops a little bit worse for our modules. Is there any way to account for the drift caused by imperfect swerve modules? or do teams generally just ignore the drift that happens during a match.\u003c/p\u003e","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":18,"updated_at":"2022-08-03T01:29:54.458Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":303,"reads":461,"readers_count":460,"score":1667.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":413892,"topic_slug":"field-relative-swervedrive-drift-even-with-simulated-perfect-modules","display_username":"Sam Belliveau","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":2,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://www.desmos.com/calculator/27a73vzmox","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"Amount to Adjust the Angle of Driving","clicks":76}],"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":4}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":39415,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Sam"},"post_url":"/t/field-relative-swervedrive-drift-even-with-simulated-perfect-modules/413892/1","custom_user_title":"Sam","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":4}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":4,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null,"can_vote":false},{"id":3075578,"name":null,"username":"anon37142155","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/a/f08c70/{size}.png","created_at":"2022-08-03T01:10:00.794Z","cooked":"\u003cp\u003eAre you guys running custom swerve modules or COTS ones? As I know SDS has base code with PIDs for their modules, which it seems that a lot of teams used, so I don’t know if they are doing anything special.\u003c/p\u003e","post_number":2,"post_type":1,"posts_count":18,"updated_at":"2022-08-03T01:10:00.794Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":425,"readers_count":424,"score":125.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":413892,"topic_slug":"field-relative-swervedrive-drift-even-with-simulated-perfect-modules","display_username":null,"primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":2}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":51083,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/field-relative-swervedrive-drift-even-with-simulated-perfect-modules/413892/2","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":2}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":2,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3075579,"name":"Sam Belliveau","username":"Sampajama","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/sampajama/{size}/180943_2.png","created_at":"2022-08-03T01:11:43.622Z","cooked":"\u003cp\u003eWe are using COTS ones, but we are using NEO’s and we are also using an absolute encoder. It still drifts when moving and turning though, due to provided PID loop not being great and there just being some fundamental math issues that cause drift.\u003c/p\u003e","post_number":3,"post_type":1,"posts_count":18,"updated_at":"2022-08-03T01:11:43.622Z","reply_count":2,"reply_to_post_number":2,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":3,"reads":417,"readers_count":416,"score":108.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":413892,"topic_slug":"field-relative-swervedrive-drift-even-with-simulated-perfect-modules","display_username":"Sam haven’t really worked with swerve so this might not work at all, but couldn’t you try to use the gyro to measure any drift that is occurring and then compensate by nudging the robot in opposite direction it is drifting.\u003c/p\u003e","post_number":4,"post_type":1,"posts_count":18,"updated_at":"2022-08-03T01:21:24.385Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":3,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":2,"reads":397,"readers_count":396,"score":89.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":413892,"topic_slug":"field-relative-swervedrive-drift-even-with-simulated-perfect-modules","display_username":null,"primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":3,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":39415,"username":"Sampajama","name":"Sam Ahmad","username":"BoiledBurntBagel","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/boiledburntbagel/{size}/223392_2.png","created_at":"2022-08-03T01:25:51.772Z","cooked":"\u003cp\u003eYou could try running a PID loop using the gyro angle as the input and the output being a target robot rotation that gets sent to the swerve modules. This would serve as an “active” method of compensating for the drift of the robot angle. This is the approach I took for the same issue on our Schreiber","username":"Mike_Schreiber","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/mike_schreiber/{size}/200098_2.png","created_at":"2022-08-03T15:08:34.791Z","cooked":"\u003cp\u003eHave you verified this behavior on a robot or is this all in the simulator?\u003c/p\u003e","post_number":11,"post_type":1,"posts_count":18,"updated_at":"2022-08-03T15:08:34.791Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":6,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":2,"reads":277,"readers_count":276,"score":65.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":413892,"topic_slug":"field-relative-swervedrive-drift-even-with-simulated-perfect-modules","display_username":"Mike Belliveau","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/sampajama/{size}/180943_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":7123,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/field-relative-swervedrive-drift-even-with-simulated-perfect-modules/413892/11","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3115483,"name":"sspoldi","username":"sspoldi","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/sspoldi/{size}/4856_2.png","created_at":"2023-01-02T17:54:08.978Z","cooked":"\u003cp\u003eWe expected that we would need to compensate for this in our field coordinates calculation. After we were happy with the body frame tuning, we adjusted the coordinate transform with a little lead compensation:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003evoid Drivetrain::ToFieldCoordinates(double *xdot, double *ydot)\u003cbr\u003e\n{\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cpre\u003e\u003ccode\u003edouble vNorth, vEast, theta;\nvNorth = *xdot;\nvEast = *ydot;\n// field coordinates conversion\ntheta = GetGyroReading() * (M_PI / 180.0);\ntheta = theta + GetGyroVel() * (M_PI / 180.0) * 0.15;\n*xdot = cos(theta) * vNorth + sin(theta) * vEast;\n*ydot = -sin(theta) * vNorth + cos(theta) * vEast;\n\u003c/code\u003e\u003c/pre\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e}\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eNote the 0.15*gyro velocity compensation to theta. That’s 150 milliseconds of effective delay (between when we measure the heading and when it gets to the motors).\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWe tuned it with the highly scientific process of spinning the robot and driving it backwards and forwards. When properly adjusted the robot would travel in the same direction spinning or not.
